column1: Before 2 October 2021, will the Taliban submit credentials to the Secretary-General of the UN to represent Afghanistan for the 76th UN General Assembly session?
column4: Yes, but their credentials will not be recognized
column5: ['Yes, and their credentials will be recognized', 'Yes, but their credentials will not be recognized', 'No']
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']
ack of credential submission has become more and more likely.

A very useful resource about the Taliban's submission of credentials: https://www.justsecurity.org/77806/expert-backgrounder-how-can-the-taliban-be-prevented-from-representing-afghanistan-in-the-united-nations/
https://kuenselonline.com/government-to-be-neutral-on-afghanistans-taliban-government-sources/

Afghan representative will not address the GA General Debate on Monday, as initially scheduled; Afghanistan has been removed from the schedule for Monday, Sep 27 (https://www.un.org/en/ga/info/meetings/76schedule.shtml), confirming earlier journalistic reports (https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/afghanistan-myanmar-will-not-address-un-general-assembly-says-official/article36696602.ece , https://tass.com/world/1342987). This removes the probability, however remote, that some state would raise a point of order, asking for the conflicting credentials to be examined ASAP.
Everything I read says that the credentials committee is likely to take its time.
UNITED NATIONS, Sept 25 (Reuters) - Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said on Saturday that international recognition of the Taliban was not currently under consideration....

They've okayed the guy from the nonexistent former gummint to represent Afghanistan until further notice: https://www.reuters.com/world/myanmar-will-not-address-world-leaders-un-afghanistan-will-2021-09-24/

The organization of governments in a diverse ideological, hostile, and tribal land is not resolved in a short number of conferences. The UN had not allowed the Taliban as a government in their last governance at the UN and allowing them may make the region more unstable by moving other groups to challenge the leadership in their lands and those in the UN. The previous government is at the UN and the Taliban may deem a fool's errand as a stain on their validity.

Although a point of order raised by some State regarding the existing representative of Afghanistan would force the Credentials Committee to meet and take a decision (or defer) immediately, this does not seem likely in the time frame of the question. The Afghan representative is scheduled to speak last in the General Debate (Sep 27); and Pakistan, which in theory could be raising such a point of order, does not seem very willing; here is an excerpt from NYT (https://archive.is/O6GTn):

Unless I'm misunderstanding the news, it looks like the Taliban has submitted credentials. So the straight no option is off there table. I don't think this goes uncontested based on the Taliban not forming an inclusive govt that meets UN standards and the previous Afghan govt also having sent a rep. So overwhelmingly likely Taliban credentials will not be recognized by oct 2

An overall impression is that what the Taliban says and what the Taliban does, are not necessary one and the same thing. There's no doubt the 'new' Taliban has learned how to appeal to the international media and is projecting a 'softer' image compared to the last time it ruled in Afghanistan. However, women's rights and female education and work has already been curtailed or disallowed; https://bit.ly/2XEMoBG. Undoubtedly there is a humanitarian crisis in Afghanistan (https://bit.ly/3CF2w5l) and the Taliban are using that information in order to gain international leverage. @Anneinak

It is unlikely (but not impossible) that the Credentials Committee will meet before the question closes on Oct 2, and such a meeting is necessary (but of course not sufficient) for recognition of the credentials.
https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/exclusive-taliban-names-afghan-un-envoy-asks-speak-world-leaders-2021-09-21/

The Taliban, who now govern Afghanistan, instructed the UN on Monday to replace Isaczai - an appointee of the country's former democratic government- with their own representative, according to a statement by the UN Secretary-General's spokesman. "I would note that the broader General Assembly goes on for some three months -- high level week, obviously, is just this week, and I don't expect this issue to be resolved within high level week. So watch the space,"
https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/21/world/taliban-unga-intl/index.html
Should have stayed with gut / initial rationale
Adjusting for the fact that the Taliban had now submitted credentials.
Updating on basis of news today, but think there is sufficient uncertainty regarding definitions of 'submission of credentials' that 'very likely' is a better choice than 'overwhelmingly unlikely'.

Well, OK, per the Reuters story it looks like the Taliban submitted a formal request to the Credentials Committee. The article I initially read merely reported that the Taliban requested that their Foreign Minister address the GA. In my opinion, the latter would not have been considered by GJO to be enough to foreclose the "No" option, but a formal submission clearly does.
Ministry of Foreign Affairs submitted September 15 to participate in the UNGA. This seems to tick off the rules needed.

Pretty widely reported now If credentials are not officially submitted then they will be soon. Now this question gets much harder! I am sitting with only a 10% chance that credentials will be challenged with a point of order AND they will then be accepted

According to all major news outlets, and contrary to some really delusional storytelling here (about supposedly too proud people, who supposedly knew that they would be rejected, so they supposedly would not even bother so that their supposedly great pride does not get supposedly hurt, despite the fact that they were perfectly able to handle rejection after rejection during their previous regime: https://www.csmonitor.com/2000/0926/p7s1.html ...), the Taliban submitted credentials to the UN Secretary General on Sep 20 for attending the 76th GA:

oups! i think i am wrong here! https://www.lapresse.ca/international/moyen-orient/2021-09-21/les-talibans-veulent-s-adresser-a-l-onu-au-nom-de-l-afghanistan.php https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/exclusive-taliban-names-afghan-un-envoy-asks-speak-world-leaders-2021-09-21/

The Taliban have asked for their Foreign Minister to address the General Assembly, but I don't think they will permit him to do so, since the previous regime's UN ambassador is slated to speak on the last day (September 27) of the current session of the GA. Having two rival Afghan diplomats address the UN would be a trifle awkward, and I'm sure the current guy has enough friends and residual good feeling among his colleagues that they probably won't step on his valedictory speech.
Reuters reports Taliban named Suhal Shaheen as Ambassador to UN. It's just a matter of time until credentials are presented.See www.reuters.com

The current delegate has been confirmed to continue to represent Afghanistan for at least the next 6 months and I suspect that this will have upset the Taliban. Why would they want this representative of the previous govt doing their international relations for them? https://www.theepochtimes.com/un-afghanistan-mission-extended-afghan-envoy-asks-to-keep-seat_4004609.html?welcomeuser=1 nice find @Anneinak
https://www.theepochtimes.com/un-afghanistan-mission-extended-afghan-envoy-asks-to-keep-seat_4004609.html

As of today, according to the AP, "the Taliban haven’t yet submitted a letter challenging the credentials of the previous government’s ambassador." https://apnews.com/article/united-nations-general-assembly-health-climate-new-york-africa-57513d3c758b613f903ad8f53bf279a1

From 1997 to 2000, both the Rabbani Government and the Taliban submitted credentials. However the Taliban were never recognized, so the probability this time is extremely unlikely, especially considering the international lack of trust in their promises to form an inclusive non-repressive government. Even countries such as China and Russia who are willing to engage with the Taliban stop short of recognition. The Taliban want international recognition which makes it plausible for them to submit credentials. However, the UNGA began on Sept 14 and is ending on Sept 27 so it seems unlikely that they will do so in the remaining week.

Basically I think there is now no chance that Taliban credentials get recognized because of non-inclusive unstable government they've formed and the fact that the previous government didn't just give up the seat and leave it open for them. However, there is still a chance that the Taliban will submit someone for credentials just to stake a claim even though they know it won't be recognized. My assessment is that its most likely they don't even bother to submit credentials since all of the news indicates that they are more concerned with domestic issues than international recognition right now.

Adjusting again with the news that the Taliban are reported to have not only closed down the "Women's Affairs Ministry" of Afghanistan but replaced it (sign and building) with the "Ministry of Virtue and Vice" [1].
Moving up 1% with passage of time. Next big move due at the opening of the 21st Sept 21.
Every regime has natural tendency to get recognition. But the performance of the Taliban govt will decide how the world react to its proposal. US & Russia & EU will be especially concerned.

Looks highly unlikely given that the official deadline has passed, but I believe there still may be an outside chance for the *application* to get in. Politically, it doesn't reflect well if a bureaucratic deadline got in the way of "averting a humanitarian crisis". I am not saying that submission of credentials or even acceptance of Taliban as a legitimate representative will lead to peace and prosperity, merely that a process-based objection isn't the smartest way to navigate these complex issues.

- Committee to recognise credentials does not routinely meet until October/November. This question ends on 2nd October, so even if the credentials are ultimately accepted, they are very unlikely to be accepted in time. - Myanmar junta have only just put forward their new representative and they took over early this year. However they may have only been incentivized to do this now because the committee is about to meet - News reports suggest there is in-fighting, and sending a UN delegate presumably requires some level of organisation and planning at the top of government - The fact that the Ghani government's representative didn't request credentials probably makes it more likely that there will not be any rush to request them/challenge them

So far, the Taliban have not challenged the delegate to the UN sent by the Ghani government. This guy has not been low profile, subtle or diplomatic in his statements about the Taliban, so I expect he will be challenged, but when? Now that the GA has begun, pressure may mount to challenge him, especially if he continues to make critical statements about the Taliban. However, in the headlines this morning was an article about infighting in the Taliban, so international diplomacy may not be high on the Taliban leadership's agenda at the moment.

As the meetings start today, the former representative will speak on behalf of Afghanistan. The Taliban has not challenged the seat. It doesn't appear to me that the new government is positioned to pursue this quite yet.
According to Reuters, as of yesterday, Sep 13, no one had yet formally claimed Afghanistan's seat for the 76th GA session:

The UN has not recognized the Taliban as having right to its power, and has criticized them for the abuse against its people. It's possible that the Taliban may eventually try to make international relations with outside countries, but right now, I think it is very much implausible that they would open themselves up to the UN, and therefore be influenced by them.

The 5 permanent members of the security council would never reach a consensus since France, the UK and the USA will not recognize the Taliban government at this time. Furthermore, their numerous human rights violations and abuses are to be considered in their membership and its international isolation will further add to making the Taliban gaining a seat unlikely.

With a press for time and a security council violently opposed to the Taliban as a ruling body, I do not see the UN accepting the credentials of the Taliban for official recognition. I think that the Taliban will need more time to establish itself as a ruling body and work to bridge the gap they face in their relations with foreign nations.

I think the Taliban may eventually do so, but the question at hand is strictly for the 76th UNGA, which is so soon it is almost unreasonable for bins 1 or 2 to occur (assumption). If they submit late, this question should resolve as one of the YES bins, but it will not be consistent with the restriction of "for the 76th UN General Assembly session."

Rush to the UN ..I don't see it. In fact the Taliban have de facto recognition. See www.guardian.com. "Afghanistan Services Collapsing Humanitarian Crisis Looms." The UN Representative UN OCHA announces 36 million Afghans endangered. Meanwhile Secretary General Gutierres. Hosting Minusters to raise emergency aid. Sounds like that they have full engagement with UN already.

The new Taliban government announced today looks a lot like the old one. No way it gets UN credentials recognized on this timeline. Only question left is whether they Taliban will even submit credentials. The composition of their government indicates that they don't care much what the international community wants them to do so they may not feel pressured to submit. On the other hand if they don't try to send someone they are effectively cedeing the UN forum to their opponents so I think there is still a decent chance they do submit credentials. https://amp-cnn-com.cdn.ampproject.org/v/s/amp.cnn.com/cnn/2021/09/07/asia/taliban-government-announcement-intl/index.html?amp_gsa=1&amp_js_v=a6&usqp=mq331AQIKAGwASCAAgM%3D#amp_tf=From%20%251%24s&aoh=16310530397874&csi=0&referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com&ampshare=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cnn.com%2F2021%2F09%2F07%2Fasia%2Ftaliban-government-announcement-intl%2Findex.html

Found this [1] to neatly summarise our understanding of the procedures, the background, historical precedent and how the situation of 1996 may be a little different to that of the Taliban's intentions regarding UNGA representation in 2021.
Updating to 0% for credentials as it is now too late for credentials to be submitted (see my below comment to @GMR's post).

Time

Today's the UNGA RoPs deadline for credential submission for the 76th session [1]: so far not a dickybird from the Taliban who seem far more excited about raising their flag over the Panjshir valley DC and setting about filling their government positions.

Adjusting a little with the added factor (well articulated by @sebbysteiny) that some perceived shaming and humiliation might be in play were the Taliban to so quickly submit credentials to the UN in the knowledge that they would likely be rejected at the door [1]. Perception, shame and humiliation are very much factors in the minds of Afghans and the Nascent Taliban regime I imagine at this moment.
In real life, things always take more time than expected. Plus, I don't think UN is on Taliban's priority for the time being at least.
Updating forecast, in line with unlikelihood of Taliban requesting credentials while knowing they don't have the numbers for the request to be granted.

It looks to me like the Taliban will seek international recognition. Consequently, they will likely object to being represented at the UN by the former government. I expect them to submit credentials, but am still unsure if there is enough time to get it done. I really don't see how the UN can recognize the Taliban right now though, despite a slight chance of some strategic effort allowing it to occur. The odds are not zero, but seem small to me (especially given the conditional requirement to submit credentials in the first place).

adjusting my forecast because I just don't see a viable path to recognition on this timeline. I'm still unsure whether the Taliban will submit credentials lots of good arguments on both sides. Basically boils down to whether you believe they need international recognition to establish legitimacy or whether you believe Afghan domestic politics are independent of international recognition. I tend to think recognition will be important to the Taliban government and that they will eventually submit credentials, but the timeline gives me pause. Is there any reason they have to do it right now knowing it will be contested vs waiting until next year and possibly being in a stronger position wrt approval? I'm waiting to see whether and how quickly they form a functioning government, if we don't see that soon then its straight no. this is the best article I've found on the history of recognition of the Afghan government https://www.lawfareblog.com/history-and-recognition-taliban?utm_campaign=Governance%20Studies&utm_medium=email&utm_content=154856488&utm_source=hs_email
Rational explained fully in https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1328916
I don’t see it as a priority for the taliban.

Some countries can have ethics reticence to recognize a government without women... https://english.alaraby.co.uk/news/taliban-announce-government-amid-panjshir-offensive?fbclid=IwAR1otqP06QrvMIsXsz_o_sCAXt9bSvfK3o_89uJK26-Yg2WN3DFKN6pU9VI

Whilst the Taliban are attempting to appear to the outside world as so-called 'Taliban 2.0', internally they will need to satisfy a lot of nationalist sentiment from the more extreme of their supporters who they're likely to lose to ISK. By not joining the UN which - is not generally viewed as a global organisation, but a western one - they will shore up support domestically of the faction within their own ranks they're most likely to lose support from.
UK will not recognise taliban
I think @Mark_T says it all; https://bit.ly/3gUwuKc. In the light of the time frame of the question, I just suspect a firmer forecast is more probable.
Just trying to stay a little bit ahead of crowd. I would be shocked if Karzai and his former finance minister are allowed into the government which would substantially change the calculus.
Given the time frame, I'm going to decay this forecast fairly quickly unless rumors surface soon.

My forecast remains but I don't budge higher because the humanitarian crisis may be motivation for the members of the UN to go soft on the Taliban in order to get aid in the country or help guide them away from the upper end of extremism. Blocking the Taliban may put a wedge into international cooperation that could otherwise aid the suffering among Afghans.
Based on conversations and rationales

In discussion with @GMR (see below), talked myself into a raise back to yesterday's original position. Time frame and the optics of dancing to the UN's calendar (rather than their own) push this back into the "much less likely" domain for me.
Adjusting back slightly again based on time available for this question.
Willing to adjust slightly on the back of well reasoned commentary from @ctsats , @lsgold7 and others on here.

I think the Taliban have behaved in ways during the fall of Kabul which demonstrate that they recognize a degree of value in international recognition. They could have made a statement by attacking Western interests directly, but they very clearly stuck to some sort of deal instead, and kept out of the way of evacuations. I think they will try, but the question is whether they will try by October 2, 2021 and the outcome.
There is no bloc that would have the votes to stop recognition. My 10% is based only on inability to get it together in time to do this.

I'm going to use the last iteration of this scenario as a base case. 20 years ago, the Taliban did submit credentials each year and the UN summarily rejected them. Therefore, I'll assume that is the most likely scenario today. However, the time is short to get the paperwork in order and I have no idea if the regime has the personnel and processes in place to get it done in time. I also don't know if the Taliban, in its current form, is interested in formal recognition at the UN or is willing and ready to take on that political fight they are sure to lose. This leads me to a lot of uncertainty, pushing me toward a neutral forecast.

@cfs_sniper lays out a particularly compelling argument (the embarrassment of being rejected and therefore waiting until they have more tacit support or legitimised standing) and a useful analysis of the potential voting blocks in play (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1327667).
Taliban is not democratically elected and recognition of their credentials would defy the spirit of rightful legitimacy.
why wouldn't they recognize the taliban

So many unknowns including internal tensions and rivalries within the Taliban itself. If these are not too great, it would make sense for them to get the country up and running as quickly and smoothly as possible, which will mean ensuring that governing bureaucracies are staffed and operational and will require a measure of trust and cooperation from the population at large. Submitting their credentials would be one way to send the reassuring message that they are serious about becoming part of a community of nations. However the move would inevitably exacerbate internal divisions and power struggles. If the Taliban leadership is not sufficiently secure, it would not make sense for them to alienate their own supporters. There must have been some quid pro quo between the US and the Taliban in recent days so it is possible that the U.S. has agreed to support such a move. Unfortunately the U.S. has squandered a lot of international credibility in recent years so even if the Taliban do submit, there is still every chance they will not be recognized.

It's an interesting question because the Taliban crave being seen as legitimate; however, with legitimacy comes implied legitimacy. I see the Taliban's ultimate goal is achieving a narco-state with no accountability and no challenges to their authority. The same 50/50 calculus that applies to the Taliban applying for recognition applies to those considering recognizing them. Do you recognize a potentially awful regime with no interest in human rights? Or do you do so specifically so that you can work to improve what they can be?

I think the Taliban have behaved in ways during the fall of Kabul which demonstrate that they recognize a degree of value in international recognition. They could have made a statement by attacking Western interests directly, but they very clearly stuck to some sort of deal instead, and kept out of the way of evacuations. I think they will try, but the question is whether they will try by October 2, 2021 and the outcome.

"The Taliban has had a longstanding interest in recognition." (see paper below on the matter) There's much to be revealed in terms of the Taliban (is this pretty much the same Taliban that is was 20 years ago or is this in any way an upgraded version? By upgraded I don't mean conscious of human rights, democracy, or international law, but different management methods, more strategic about governing and power control instead of just ruling by terror. The international community will set the conditions for any such recognition and that will take time if the Taliban decides to play nice. The UN general assembly is taking place Sept 14-27 so it might be a matter of how much legitimacy and attention the Taliban would want from the world from the get-go even if the odds of formal UN recognition is out of the question.
This is not the highest priority for the Taliban. If they do, the UN will not be in a position to recognize a new government as legitimate by the question close date.
Evidence of chaos within the taliban is growing and they may start to fracture. No is moving up in my forecast, credentials recognized is moving way down.
From what I read I suppose they want to be recognised, however, the time-frame of the 2 October seems quite narrow and their grip on the country doesn't look full stabilised.
It is a fact that Taliban wants recognition so they will prioritize submit credentials but ONU will not recognize credentials from a such incipient govern with so much instability.

If credentials must be presented 7 days before the general assembly then the Taliban has about 9 days to get that done. I will watch the level of chaos and I am starting to move no up and yes credentials will be recognized down.
#reminder

Taliban desperate for recogonition and will leverage aid and other stuff to get accepted. Support from China and Russia predictable but deferring possible like in the 90s and still alot for Taliban to arrange before Sept 14

Who is the rightful govt of Afghanistan? And who do the UN member states want to recognise? That may be the question we need to consider. Myreading makes points me to the following: Back in the90s and early 2000s when the talibs were last in power the UN provisionally kept the previous administrations representative to the Afghan permanent mission to the UN by deferring their decision on a new representative. When ever the taliban put forward credentials the decision was deferred. This could happen again if the world doesnt think that the taliban has instated a representative govt (it doesnt seem to necessarily be a democratic govt). The credentials committee deferred the Talibans submissions for at least 9 years last time around. https://www.csmonitor.com/2000/0926/p7s1.html https://www.un.org/press/en/1996/19961011.ga9127.html

They don't seem to respect international laws and are more inclined to follow Islam principles. For one, the chance they want to is unclear. Second, the chance they know how to is also unclear. And so on.

So this question closes in a month. The sub questions are 1) will the old government seek to continue representing afghanistan at the UN general assembly? we don't know yet. https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-diplomats-continue-contacts-with-taliban-doha-says-state-department-2021-08-16/ https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-58260902 2) will the taliban government seek credentials before October? also unclear, obviously they want international recognition but they haven't even fully formed a government yet, although they are working on it. https://apnews.com/article/afghanistan-taliban-kabul-1d4b052ccef113adc8dc94f965ff23c7 https://www.mei.edu/publications/taliban-and-formation-new-afghan-government

There is a de facto leader of the Taliban in Kabul (https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/burns-afghanistan-baradar-biden/2021/08/24/c96bee5c-04ba-11ec-ba15-9c4f59a60478_story.html) with different factions and leaders trying to form an inclusive government or, in other words vying for power and a seat at the table. There is no semblance of a government yet. There is a narrow window of time to legitimize a government that could legitimately provide the credentials to the UN. for a representative. “Defacto” probably does not a strong enough standing. Over throwing one government does not necessarily mean control is established

This question comes up 35 days, not much time and that will influence my forecasts. Will the Taliban present credentials? Yes, they have wanted that in the past and UN recognition would legitimize their rule. It is a small possibility that things get so chaotic and unstable that they do not get their act together to present credentials, but it appears to be a straightforward process and doable in 35 days. Will the credentials be accepted? Probably not. 35 days is not enough time for the Taliban to establish changed behavior from their past rule. The argument can be made that the UN would want stability and Afghanistan to not be a haven for terrorists of all kinds. It appears they cannot control ISIS and as for stability that would take time to demonstrate. Western democratic governments would also have political problems at home if they were openly in favor of a government that came to power by force, does not recognize women’s rights and other basic human rights. Middle east and Islamic dictatorships may also be leery of recognizing a government that will provide a base for terrorists. What I would like to know is if the previous government will make a claim as the legitimate government in exile.

1 - If Taiwan is not recognize... how can Afghanistan can be recognize within a month? ... i dont say that Taiwan should or should not be recognize, but the time frame is very short for some countries recently involved. For example, politicians from Canada consider talibans as a terrorist group. Every country involve in the last episode of the airport evacuation need some time to reframe their mind, and their constituants; 2- Feminist group inside some occidental countries have a lot of influence. There are election in Germany and Canada... fearing of feminist reaction in regard of taliban toward women rights can be a political instinct; 3- Dissensions in the country will happen sooner or later... probably before october 2. So what we see now like an unified country will not be the same in some days. Ethnic, regional power, religious group... old lord of war will soon arise against Taliban, The actual perception of unity will soon disapear and will be reason or interest to not recognize this country; 4- Maybe Taliban wont be enough organize to submit their credentials. I am not taking for a certitude that a well and organized government can be able to take in charge this country... and make the decision to submit credentials.

A two-thirds majority vote is necessary in the Assembly for admission of a new State. https://www.un.org/en/about-us/about-un-membership About 1/3 of the nations are western and another 1/3 Islamic. The UN as an org has an incentive to allow new members and S Sudan was given a unanimous vote. Security council has less sway. I think overall the world has more interest in stability in Afghanistan than a break up. I think that US is a puppeteer in rapid rise of Taliban, for example pulling funds from Kabul Gov. My intuition is that if the Taliban are successful at human rights and form a somewhat inclusive gov, the US will be an unofficial sponsor. I think that China and Russia also have an interest in Terror free Afghanistan. India may still be threatened by a unified Afghanistan.
